Award.AwardTitle: CChIPS (Center for Child Injury Prevention Studies) at The Ohio State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal describes the plans for The Ohio State University (OSU) to join the Center for Child Injury Prevention Studies (CChIPS) as a NSF funded Multi-University Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC). CChIPS is the nations first and only I/UCRC focused on child injury prevention, with a specific emphasis on injury due to traffic accidents. The mission of CCHIPS is to advance the safety of children, youth, and young adults (through age 24 years) by facilitating the conduct of scientific inquiry into their injuries and by translating these findings into commercial applications, interventions, policies, and public education programs for prevention. The initial technical focus of the Ohio State site will be the same standard defined by CChIPS over the last five years, but with an emphasis on sports related injuries, including concussion issues for children, youth, and young adults.

The broader impact of this center with the inclusion of the Ohio State University will be the saving of lives; lives of children and young adults. By preventing the needless loss of life, the economic benefits are also apparent with reduced need for medical personnel in the treatment of crash injuries. This should free up the resources and make them available for other medical priorities. The proposed effort will educate students in this field as well as educate the general public via the knowledge created from the work.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since joining the Center for Child Injury Prevention Studies (CChIPS) in 2011, The Ohio State University has been collaborating with the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP) to support the CChIPS’ mission – to advance the safety of children, youth, and young adults by facilitating scientific inquiry into childhood and young adult injuries and to translate these findings into commercial applications and public education programs for preventing future injuries. The OSU branch of CChIPS is made up of a diverse group of researchers with expertise in anatomy, anthropology, athletic training, and engineering.

Through CChIPS, OSU has conducted 15 research projects focusing on the areas of child passenger injury and mechanisms, biofidelity of child anthropomorphic test devices (ATDs), child restraint system (CRS) interactions with vehicles, and safety promotion and education.

There have been major outcomes from OSU’s CChIPS partnership including:

The development of a community outreach and education initiative to translate research findings and promote child passenger safety to parents and caregivers. Buckle Up with Brutus provides proper car seat usage information to central Ohio through its website (http://buckleup.osu.edu), social media, and community events. This initiative provides CChIPS researchers with a communication vehicle that reaches areas of the general public most concerned with the results of their research.

Assessments of child restraint system (CRS) installations within the interior of the vehicles have documented incompatibilities between CRS and vehicle seats that could lead to child injuries. With over 60 CRS’ tested in more than 70 vehicles, a robust dataset has been established to provide manufacturers with recommendations for CRS designs to improve compatibility and to provide caregivers with a guide to choosing the best car seat to fit in their vehicle type.

Research focusing on the biofidelity of child-sized crash test dummies has helped make these dummies’ bodies behave more like a child’s, leading to greater understanding of child injury mechanisms. This knowledge of injury mechanisms, helps industry members better understand how to design better child restraint systems for cars to better protect children in crashes.  The dummies can then be used to test the safety systems to ensure they are better protecting kids.

 


Last Modified: 02/08/2017
Modified by: John H Bolte
